title: 104_hr4203
content: The Act is titled the "First Flight Commemorative Coin Act" and outlines specifications for the coin. The "First Flight Commemorative Coin Act" authorizes the minting of $10 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and metal compositions. The coins minted under the "First Flight Commemorative Coin Act" must have a diameter of 1.205 inches and meet the specifications for half dollar coins. The Secretary of the Treasury can reduce the maximum amounts minted if there is insufficient public demand. These coins will be legal tender. The Secretary will obtain gold and silver for minting coins as authorized by other laws, including the use of silver stockpiles. The design of the coins will be determined under this Act. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the first flight of Orville and Wilbur Wright in Kitty Hawk, North Carolina in 1903. Each coin will feature a value designation, the year "2003", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the First Flight Foundation and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design of the coins minted under this Act will symbolize the first flight of Orville and Wilbur Wright in Kitty Hawk, North Carolina in 1903. Each coin will feature a value designation, the year "2003", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The Secretary may issue coins minted under this Act from August 1, 2003, to July 31, 2004, with a possible 5-year extension if there is sufficient public demand. The coins issued under the Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. A surcharge of $35 per coin will be included for the $10 coin. The Secretary will sell coins at face value plus surcharge and design costs. Bulk sales and prepaid orders will have discounts. Marketing plan and funds will be ensured for coins minted under the Act. SEC. 7 of the Act waives procurement regulations for goods and services needed for the Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8 addresses the distribution of surcharges from coin sales. SEC. 8 of the Act directs all surcharges from coin sales to be paid to the First Flight Foundation for maintaining the Wright Brothers Monument and National Memorial Park in North Carolina. The Comptroller General has the right to audit the Foundation's expenditures. SEC. 9 addresses financial assurances. SEC. 9 of the Act requires the Secretary to ensure that minting coins will not cost the government. SEC. 10 states that the Act will not take effect until January 1, 1998.
